location: England, Sussex, Chichester, A27 Westhampnett Bypass
tags: cremation, pre-roman, roman, early medieval, funerary, cremation, shrine
description: An exceptional cremation ground found just outside of Chichester along the route of the A27 Westhampnett Bypass in 1992 by Wessex Archaeology. The site contained burials from the Late Iron Age, Roman, and early Anglo-Saxon periods together with a probable Bronze Age ring ditch. The excavators identified four rectangular or square trench-built timber structures (20277, 20657, 20761, and 20562) to the north-east of a circular burial space as shrines.
bibliography: Martyn, Blick, Brindle, et al, (2015), Westhampnett, Area 3 (West Sussex), available at: https://doi.org/10.5284/1030449
Martyn, Blick, Brindle, et al, (2015), Westhampnett, Area 2 (West Sussex), available at: https://doi.org/10.5284/1030449
Fitzpatrick, A., Powell, A., Allen, M., (2008), Archaeological Excavations on the Route of the A27 Westhampnett Bypass, West Sussex, 1992, pg. 15 - 18
Rudling, D., (2008), Roman-Period temples, shrines and religion in sussex, in Ritual Landscapes of Roman South-East Britain, pg. 95, 97
Fitzpatrick, (1997), Archaeological excavations on the route of the A27 Westhampnett Bypass, West Sussex, 1992, 2
